data.event: The area around Beaconsfield was first explored by Europeans in 1804 when William Paterson led an expedition to Port Dalrymple and established a settlement at York Town.
Limestone mining led to the discovery of gold in 1869.
Gold mining began in 1877 and the area's population boomed.
Brandy Creek Post Office opened on 1 December 1877 and was renamed Beaconsfield in 1879.
Brandy Creek Post Office opened on 1 December 1877 and was renamed Beaconsfield in 1879.
The town was named Beaconsfield in 1879 in honour of Benjamin Disraeli, 1st Earl of Beaconsfield, who was the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom at the time.
In 1881, the Beaconsfield newspaper was called the Beaconsfield Tickler.
Gold was first discovered in Beaconsfield in 1847.

event.title: hit Victoria and New South Wales in 1851

data.event: When the gold rush hit Victoria and New South Wales in 1851 and the Tasmanian Government offered a reward for the discovery of a payable goldfield.

event.title: 1877 the cap of a payable gold reef was discovered

data.event: In 1877 the cap of a payable gold reef was discovered on the eastern slope of Cabbage Tree Hill by brothers William and David Dally.
In October 1877 the Dally brothers sold their claim on the Tasmania Reef to William D Grubb & William Hart for 15,000 pounds, and 1/10 share in any company formed.
In October 1877 the Dally brothers sold their claim on the Tasmania Reef to William D Grubb & William Hart for 15,000 pounds, and 1/10 share in any company formed.
